articles.headline: A Flurry of Recalls at G.M. as Pressure Mounts
articles.snippet: The latest recalls by General Motors bring the total to more than 13 million vehicles in the United States this year.
articles.abstract: The latest recalls by General Motors bring the total to more than 13 million vehicles in the United States this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors issued four new recalls on Tuesday, bringing its total for the year to 13.5 million vehicles, already the most in the company’s history.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: Far-Right Fever for a Europe Tied to Russia
articles.snippet: Nationalist movements across Europe are stressing Russia’s role as a counterweight to American power over the Continent.
articles.abstract: Nationalist movements across Europe are stressing Russia’s role as a counterweight to American power over the Continent.
articles.lead_paragraph: LE CHESNAY, France — At a rally last week near the Palace of Versailles, France’s largest far-right party, the National Front, deployed all the familiar theatrics and populist themes of nationalist movements across Europe.

articles.headline: Alarm Over Istanbul’s Building Boom
articles.snippet: Real estate development in the Turkish city, fueled by cheap money and official encouragement, reminds some of what happened in Spain and Ireland.
articles.abstract: Real estate development in the Turkish city, fueled by cheap money and official encouragement, reminds some of what happened in Spain and Ireland.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — “We are invading Istanbul again,” the real estate agent said enthusiastically as she ticked off the selling points of Turkey’s most ambitious development extravaganza to date: Maslak 1453.

articles.headline: Arthur Gelb, Critic and Editor Who Shaped The Times, Dies at 90
articles.snippet: By force of personality, Mr. Gelb was a dominant figure in the newsroom at The New York Times, lifting its metropolitan and arts coverage to new heights.
articles.abstract: By force of personality, Mr. Gelb was a dominant figure in the newsroom at The New York Times, lifting its metropolitan and arts coverage to new heights.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arthur Gelb, who by sheer force of personality was a dominant figure at The New York Times for decades, lifting its metropolitan and arts coverage to new heights and helping to shape the paper in its modern era, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

articles.headline: For Schools, Long Road to a Level Playing Field
articles.snippet: The United States, which lags most other industrial nations in educational performance, also has a persistent gulf in the test results between the rich and the poor.
articles.abstract: The United States, which lags most other industrial nations in educational performance, also has a persistent gulf in the test results between the rich and the poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the American national mythology, there are few more revered ideas than the belief in education’s power to provide every child a shot at success and to overcome entrenched inequality.

articles.headline: After Fed, Bernanke Offers His Wisdom, for a Big Fee
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, is poised to make millions of dollars from speaking engagements this year.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, is poised to make millions of dollars from speaking engagements this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Ben S. Bernanke spoke in Abu Dhabi; on Wednesday, he was in Johannesburg. By Friday, he was in Houston. That week in March was a particularly busy one for Mr. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve.

articles.headline: Fine Line Seen in U.S. Spying on Companies
articles.snippet: United States officials say the N.S.A. is free to spy on trade negotiators to help American trade officials, and by extension, American industries and workers they are trying to bolster.
articles.abstract: United States officials say the N.S.A. is free to spy on trade negotiators to help American trade officials, and by extension, American industries and workers they are trying to bolster.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has never said what it was seeking when it invaded the computers of Petrobras, Brazil’s huge national oil company, but angry Brazilians have guesses: the company’s troves of data on Brazil’s offshore oil reserves, or perhaps its plans for allocating licenses for exploration to foreign companies.

articles.headline: China and Russia Reach 30-Year Gas Deal
articles.snippet: Capping a decade-long negotiation, the two countries agreed on Wednesday to a deal, expected to be worth about $400 billion, that would send gas from Siberia by pipeline to China.
articles.abstract: Capping a decade-long negotiation, the two countries agreed on Wednesday to a deal, expected to be worth about $400 billion, that would send gas from Siberia by pipeline to China.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China and Russia signed a $400 billion gas deal on Wednesday, giving Moscow a megamarket for its leading export and linking two major powers that, despite a rocky history of alliances and rivalries, have drawn closer to counter the clout of the United States and Europe.
